author: cperezz.eth
content:
Does anyone here know why do we support up to 1024 byte inputs in https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-7823.md istead of going way lower than that? Is there any contract that actually requires this (I can only think RSA verification and is not even worth supporting most likely)? 

My assumption was that 32bytes will do for almost any case (most EC stuff that is non-native for example).

Thus, removing the issue of MODEXP completely with much more bounded inputs and much bounded gas_estimation costs.

author: celtic.warrior
content: Just a heads up on the topic of gas limit as the core devs may not be generally aware: the default gas limit for SSV is still 30 million.  Right now, SSV accounts for >10% of the validator set.  While the gas limit is configurable at the SSV client, I would guess that the majority of SSV users are not aware of this.  And setting the gas limit is not configurable at the user level, only at the operator level. Which has some additional complexity because of the threshold signing that is needed per SSV cluster. It might be worth factoring this into your discussions on the topic.  A special kind of centralization risk related to DVT...

author: tersec
content: but if the rest of the network moves to 45M (for example), they'll make 45M blocks?

author: siladu
content:
Yes. Network is on 36M already https://gaslimit.pics/
so any node should be producing/processing roughly these size blocks. 

If they are configured for 30M then they pull the network gas limit slightly down from 36M for their block, but then it goes back up to 36M since majority of blocks are that. 
Actually, a significant number are 60M so it can be above 36M too depending on the order of proposers and their gas limit config...

e.g. from graffiti this appears to be ssv block: https://beaconcha.in/slot/11959189
Gas Limit: 36140173
previous block was https://beaconcha.in/slot/11959187 
Gas Limit: 36175499 gas limit (so ssv pulled it down with their 30M gas limit block)

another example from 36M -> 30M:
ssv block: https://beaconcha.in/slot/11957362
Gas Limit: 35964811
previous block: https://beaconcha.in/slot/11957361
Gas Limit: 35999966

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Regarding the R1 precompile. I feel its significantly underpriced compared to ECRecover. In a synthetic benchmark, we get ~110MGas/s for K1 and ~62MGas/s for R1.
I would be interested in seeing the numbers from other client teams before ACD today cc <@&652918665943056397> <@&836981603216654336> <@&1070471163219824730>

author: ansgar.eth
content:
devnet-2
- EIP-7951 included, pricing as-is
- EIP-7907 included (old version, without PR)
- EIP-7934 included
- EIP-7939 included

author: ansgar.eth
content:
devnet-3
- EIP-7951 pricing
- EIP-7907 new version
- EIP-7918 parameter change to `2**13`
- per-tx blob max move to peerdas EIP

author: ansgar.eth
content:
EIP Status
- EIP-7951: move to SFI
- EIP-7907: move to SFI
- EIP-7934: move to SFI
- EIP-7939: add to SFI
- EIP-7975: keep out of Fusaka Meta-EIP for now

author: ansgar.eth
content: let me know if it looks like I made a mistake on any of these, a lot to keep track of during the call

author: frozenfire.eth
content: Why would RSA verification not be worth supporting? Our product depends on RSA verification

author: frozenfire.eth
content: Currently looking at using modexp for modular reduction, which I could see needing upwards of 1024-byte inputs in certain cases (reduction of 8192-bit products over a 4096-bit modulus).
